    run_anova

    run_anova.Rmd

    Introduction

    The run_anova function is designed to perform a one-sample ANOVA test on a numeric variable to compare its mean against a specified value (default is 0). This function provides the ANOVA summary table, the F-statistic, and p-value, and additionally runs a t-test to compare the mean of the numeric variable against a hypothesized value.

    Installation Instructions

    To use this function, you will first need to install the package and load it into your R environment.

    devtools::install_github("kaitlinlanguirand/Project_3")
#> Using GitHub PAT from the git credential store.
#> Skipping install of 'LanguirandR' from a github remote, the SHA1 (ca334e3e) has not changed since last install.
#>   Use `force = TRUE` to force installation
library(LanguirandR)
#> Loading required package: tidyverse
#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──

    Example

    Download Data

    To demonstrate the function, download example data files from the repository and load them into R:

    download.file("https://github.com/kaitlinlanguirand/Project_3/raw/refs/heads/main/datasets_project3/log_1.log", "datasets_project3/log_1.log")
#> Warning in
#> download.file("https://github.com/kaitlinlanguirand/Project_3/raw/refs/heads/main/datasets_project3/log_1.log",
#> : URL
#> https://github.com/kaitlinlanguirand/Project_3/raw/refs/heads/main/datasets_project3/log_1.log:
#> cannot open destfile 'datasets_project3/log_1.log', reason 'No such file or
#> directory'
#> Warning in
#> download.file("https://github.com/kaitlinlanguirand/Project_3/raw/refs/heads/main/datasets_project3/log_1.log",
#> : download had nonzero exit status

log_1 <- read_table("/cloud/project/datasets_project3/log_1.log")
#> 
#> ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> cols(
#>   .default = col_double()
#> )
#> ℹ Use `spec()` for the full column specifications.

    Use Function

    You can use the run_anova function to test the mean of a numeric column. In the example below, we test the Posterior column of log_1 against a hypothesized mean of 0.

    LanguirandR::run_anova(log_1, "Posterior", mu = 0) 
#> One-Sample ANOVA F-statistic: NA
#> One-Sample ANOVA p-value: NA
#> T-test results for mean comparison against 0: p-value = 0
#> $anova_summary
#>              Df   Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F)
#> Residuals   600 57600204   96000               
#> 
#> $t_test_result
#> 
#>  One Sample t-test
#> 
#> data:  df[[numeric_column]]
#> t = -300.09, df = 600, p-value < 2.2e-16
#> alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 0
#> 95 percent confidence interval:
#>  -3817.502 -3767.860
#> sample estimates:
#> mean of x 
#> -3792.681

    Conclusion

    The run_anova function provides a simple and efficient way to test if a numeric variable’s mean significantly differs from a hypothesized value. It combines ANOVA and t-test results to give a comprehensive statistical summary.

    Developed by Kaitlin Languirand.
